pattern_sources.name: 52 Weeks of Sweaters | 52 x Villapaidat
pattern_sources.notes:
*52 Weeks of Sweaters* is the eighth volume in Laine Publishing’s hugely popular 52 Weeks book series — and the most-requested subject! The book features 52 patterns by 52 talented designers from all over the world, expanding the theme beyond sweaters to cardigans, vests and slipovers as well. You’ll find a wide range of techniques from simple stockinette stitch to textures, colourwork and cables (and even one crochet piece!).  
 
The projects’ skill level ranges from easy to challenging, and they showcase just how versatile knitted garments can be: from delicate cardigans to layer over your party dress, to cosy jumpers that double as outerwear. Truly, a sweater book to inspire everyone! 

**Publication date:** 19 February, 2026
An identical ebook is also available through Laine publishing.

pattern_sources.author: Maja Kløvdal
pattern_sources.name: Other Loops_
pattern_sources.notes:
Other Loops / otherloops.com

> If you have questions, comments or
> need knitting support, you are welcome
> to write to us on
> support@otherloops.com

 

Behind Other Loops you will meet up with Maja Kløvdal, who has a degree as fashion designer from the Design School Kolding in Denmark “DK:DK” Since her education, Maja has made a career in the fashion industry, where she has worked and accelerated the growth for several well-known Danish fashion brands.

Other Loops are born from Maja’s dream of making more slow fashion and returning to her own roots, which is to create and develop on the actual craft.
Maja focus on aesthetics, quality and details that go side by side with the traditions of Scandinavian design.

Maja create classic and modern knitwear patterns that suite your needs of long-lasting design. Other Loops put heart into developing precise patterns that are straight forward for you to understand, so your personal knitting skills elevate up to next level.

Otherloops.com develop aesthetic quality design for you and the future to come.

For more inspiration you can also follow the brand on Instagram @otherloops
If you have questions, comments or need knitting support, you are welcome to write to us on support@otherloops.com 
Pattern is solely for private use and must not be copied, resold, or shared. Products made from the patterns may not be sold.

> If you have questions, comments or
> need knitting support, you are welcome
> to write to us on
> support@otherloops.com

Happy loops!

pattern_sources.name: Lindsey Muscarella's Ravelry Store
pattern_sources.notes: Hey everyone! If you like cozy, size inclusive, and a little bit of camp, then you've come to the right place! All of my designs are meant to fit all bodies and can be easily adjusted! If you have any questions please reach out here or send me a message at justtheworsted@gmail.com.

pattern_sources.author: Sirdar
pattern_sources.name: Sirdar Ravelry Store
pattern_sources.notes:
***[Sirdar](https://sirdar.com)***   

It's a name you might have heard from your mum or grandmother. But wherever you first heard our name, you'll know that handknitters have passed their love of Sirdar yarns from generation to generation.

Established in West Yorkshire in 1880, we believe we've earned our place at the heart of the British knitting community, as well as our growing reputation around the world for yarn innovation and trend-led design.

*We rigorously test every Sirdar yarn so you can rely on our quality. And we triple check every Sirdar pattern so you can be sure of a successful knit with the recommended Sirdar yarn.*

That's why the Sirdar logo has become a reliable mark of quality for hand knitting yarns and patterns.

**Hand knitting is in our genes.**

pattern_sources.name: Tsukuru
pattern_sources.notes:
Defunct Japanese pattern selling site, including patterns from Nihon Vogue publications.

**Note:** You must be a member of Tsukuru to download their patterns (whether free or paid). Registration is free but only in Japanese. If you need help figuring out how to register, ask for help in the [Japanese knitting & crochet group][1].


  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/japanese-knitting-and-crochet

pattern_sources.name: Internet Archive (Wayback Machine)
pattern_sources.notes:
The Wayback Machine is a digital archive of the World Wide Web and other information on the Internet

**This source should only be used when a digital pattern is no longer accessible at its original online source. DO NOT add archive links and sources to designer linked patterns**

pattern_sources.author: Christina Probert, ed.
pattern_sources.name: Knitting in Vogue Number 3
pattern_sources.notes:
Patterns from the 1930s to the 1980s for men, women & children 

168 pages, © 1985.

Colour photographs by Mario Testino.

**Publishing Notes:**
1985
Australia - 0333400801 South Melbourne Macmillan
England - 0715386182 Newton Abbot David & Charles.

Identical to [Great Knitting in Vogue][1], USA (1985), apart from the frontispiece, cover and title page. 

1988
Knitting in Vogue *(N.B. without number)*  - 1858521255 was published by Peerage Books in the UK in 1988. Boy in knit vest and plaid shirt on cover (no dustjacket). 

There are also books with this second photograph which appear to be a repackaging of the 1985 UK edition - i.e. with the 1985 title, ISBN and publisher within the book itself, but the new 1988 title, ISBN and publisher on the dustjacket.

  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/great-knitting-in-vogue

pattern_sources.author: Christina Probert, ed.
pattern_sources.label: St. Martin's Press
pattern_sources.name: Great Knitting in Vogue
pattern_sources.notes:
Over 70 classic Vogue patterns for women, men and children, updated for today's knitter.

168 pages, © 1985.

Colour photographs by Mario Testino.

**Publishing Notes:**
1985 - 0312346107 St Martin's Press New York USA. The first edition has a different picture on the dust jacket - a woman and young boy both wearing sweaters.

Published as [Knitting in Vogue Number 3][1] in UK and Australia.


  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/knitting-in-vogue-number-3

pattern_sources.notes:
Besides being well known for the originality and the high quality of their hand-dyed self-patterning yarns, [Biscotte Yarns][1] has also established a strong reputation in designing and creating original knitting designs. They like to play with colored stripes in every way and their designs stand out by her unique style that challenges traditional knitting techniques and the quality of their composition. 

**Several patterns are available free of charge... [Subscribe to Biscotte Yarns Newsletter][2] to never miss a new release**

pattern_sources.author: Sirdar
pattern_sources.name: Sirdar Ravelry Store
pattern_sources.notes:
***[Sirdar](https://sirdar.com)***   

It's a name you might have heard from your mum or grandmother. But wherever you first heard our name, you'll know that handknitters have passed their love of Sirdar yarns from generation to generation.

Established in West Yorkshire in 1880, we believe we've earned our place at the heart of the British knitting community, as well as our growing reputation around the world for yarn innovation and trend-led design.

*We rigorously test every Sirdar yarn so you can rely on our quality. And we triple check every Sirdar pattern so you can be sure of a successful knit with the recommended Sirdar yarn.*

That's why the Sirdar logo has become a reliable mark of quality for hand knitting yarns and patterns.

**Hand knitting is in our genes.**

pattern_sources.name: Cuello y Sweater Historia
pattern_sources.notes:
Jamás imagine que iba a tejer y vestir una prenda así, tan llena de color y desestructurada pero me animé, me sorprendí y me enamoré.

Mi invitación en este patrón es que te animes como yo a jugar con los colores, que no lo pienses tanto y dejes fluir el hilado entre tus manos y la aguja. Te prometo que cuando termines de tejerlo vas a enamorarte como yo.

El diseño del Cuello Historia surgió luego de terminar el Sweater Historia. Hace mucho tiempo quería tejer un cuello que tuviera un peto circular y me enamoré tanto del sweater que tome un poquito de aquí y de allá y nació este hermoso cuello que, por supuesto, también se puede convertir en sweater si lo complementas con la guía de tejido y, por que no, en una capa o un poncho. ¡Las posibilidades son infinitas!

En este pátrón no vas a encontrar tabla de talles y esto es sencillamente porque todos los cuerpos son diferentes y me gusta enseñarte de tal manera que puedas adaptar la prenda a tu propias medias además de brindarte herramientas que te sirvan para futuros proyectos y, por que no, para que comiences a diseñar tus propias prendas.

**¿Qué vas a encontrar en este patrón?**

* Un archivo PDF con toda la información y herramientas que necesitas para llevar a cabo estos proyectos
* Gráficos, esquemas y fotos
* 4 Videos tutoriales para realizar el Cuello Historia que te servirán de apoyo para tejer el sweater
* Consejos, sugerencias y tips

**Detalles:**

Dificultad: Fácil, apto para principiantes
Talles: A medida
Hilado: El que más te guste!
Aguja: La que quieras para tu hilado
Materiales adicionales: Tijeras, aguja lanera, centímetro y marcadores de puntos
Cantidad necesaria: para mi sweater utilicé aproximadamente 650 gramos de acrílico 4/7 y para mi cuello 120 gramos del mismo hilado (esto va a variar dependiendo de tu forma de tejer, el hilado y aguja que uses, el talle, etc.)

> **SI SOS DE ARGENTINA** podes adquirir esta guía **[AQUI][1]**


  [1]: https://www.tejidosmel.com.ar/patrones/cuello-y-sweater-historia-patron-crochet

pattern_sources.author: Alicia Plummer
pattern_sources.name: Two Little Plums
pattern_sources.notes:
I write knitting patterns because I can tell a story with my hands.  Each pattern is designed around a memory or a feeling that I’ve experienced...and it’s also a canvas for you to make it your own. 
Patterns to live life in.

pattern_sources.author: Alexa Ludeman and Emily Wessel
pattern_sources.name: The Simple Collection
pattern_sources.notes:
**The Simple Collection ::: learn to knit with Alexa and Emily**

This year at Tin Can Knits we explore the basic ingredients of knitting.  The Simple Collection has quick accessories and simple sweaters, sized from baby to big and best of all **– the patterns are all free for you to use and share with your friends!** 

With free patterns (including sweaters!) and clear tutorials, the collection is perfect for newer knitters building skills and confidence; and also a treat for knitters who enjoy modern lines and simple details. Whether you are knitting your first scarf, socks, or sweater, the Simple Collection will teach you all you need to know to make modern seamless knits for the whole family!

pattern_sources.author: Anne Ventzel
pattern_sources.name: Anne Ventzel Ravelry Store
pattern_sources.notes:
My name is Anne Ventzel and I am a Danish designer based in Copenhagen, Denmark.

For almost 20 years I have worked in the Danish fashion industry and designed for others. Since the publication of my first knitting pattern in 2016, the craft, I love so much, has filled more and more in my life. In 2019 I opened my business with hand-knitted projects. It has since grown, and today I am working as 100% independent on my own designs.

[Website][1]

You can follow my work on instagram: @anneventzel

If you have comments, questions or need knitting support, you are always welcome to write to us on info@anneventzel.com

And on my YouTube channel you find my knitting tips for the patterns.

Please note that the knitting patterns are for private use only. The patterns may not be copied, sold or otherwise distributed. Products made from the patterns may not be sold.

 Instagram: anneventzel


  [1]: http://www.anneventzel.com

pattern_sources.author: Alexa Ludeman and Emily Wessel
pattern_sources.name: Basics
pattern_sources.notes:
Get all four Basics patterns!

We are getting back to basics! Whether you're knitting your very first hat or your 100th sweater, you'll love these wardrobe classics. They're destined to become some of your favourite pieces.

These knits are designed with knitters in mind. All the knitters. Each pattern has our signature baby-to-big size range, AND in multiple yarn weights. This way you can grab your favourite yarn and GO! 

With our new patterns come new tutorials on everything you need to complete your project! [Get our emails to learn more][1].

~ Alexa and Emily


  [1]: https://tincanknits.com/contact

pattern_sources.author: Maja Kløvdal
pattern_sources.name: Other Loops_
pattern_sources.notes:
Other Loops / otherloops.com

> If you have questions, comments or
> need knitting support, you are welcome
> to write to us on
> support@otherloops.com

 

Behind Other Loops you will meet up with Maja Kløvdal, who has a degree as fashion designer from the Design School Kolding in Denmark “DK:DK” Since her education, Maja has made a career in the fashion industry, where she has worked and accelerated the growth for several well-known Danish fashion brands.

Other Loops are born from Maja’s dream of making more slow fashion and returning to her own roots, which is to create and develop on the actual craft.
Maja focus on aesthetics, quality and details that go side by side with the traditions of Scandinavian design.

Maja create classic and modern knitwear patterns that suite your needs of long-lasting design. Other Loops put heart into developing precise patterns that are straight forward for you to understand, so your personal knitting skills elevate up to next level.

Otherloops.com develop aesthetic quality design for you and the future to come.

For more inspiration you can also follow the brand on Instagram @otherloops
If you have questions, comments or need knitting support, you are welcome to write to us on support@otherloops.com 
Pattern is solely for private use and must not be copied, resold, or shared. Products made from the patterns may not be sold.

> If you have questions, comments or
> need knitting support, you are welcome
> to write to us on
> support@otherloops.com

Happy loops!
